p: Extracts and compounds were evaluated as bacterial growth inhibitors against wild type, norA-deleted, and norA-overexpressing strains of S. aureus. According to Duarte et al. (2007); Wang et al. (2008), and Oliveira et al. (2013) plant extracts can be classified as antibacterial agents according to their MIC values; MIC < 500 μg/mL indicate strong inhibitors, MIC between 600 and 1,500 μg/mL indicate moderate inhibitors, and MIC > 1,600 μg/mL indicate weak inhibitors. Therefore, the EO and extracts from P. uviferum heartwood can be classified as strong inhibitors showing MIC range of 31.3–500 μg/mL in all evaluated S. aureus strains. Additionally, the analyses showed that the MIC values were the lowest in the K1902 (Δ norA) strain. Wild type and K2378 (overexpressing norA) S. aureus possessed high levels of antimicrobial resistance because they were capable of reducing the intracellular antibacterial agent concentration via efflux, which was partly mediated by NorA pumps. These pumps were absent in K1902 norA-deleted (Δ norA) cells.
